data.title: Opinion: Holy Roman Empire was a Roman successor state
data.meta_description: I will even go further in declaring the Ottoman Empire also as a successor of the Roman Empire.
data.text:

It was an adoption by a Germanic power [Lombards did the same in Italy becoming "the fathers of Italy"].

It wasn't exactly a state, very much in the modern understanding of what a state is, and what it does.

The early US copied its aesthetics and rethoric, but that doesn't mean they had a full understanding, or grasp, of how the Roman Empire was actually organized, and how Roman central power was emanated to the provinces.

The Roman Empire was more of a loose and interconnected self-administered number of city-states that followed a set of rules, norms, and the culture that were emanated from Rome, the big metropolis. Most of the administrative power of the Emperor and the Senate of Rome had on its provinces were pretty much only concerning military and religious affairs. Everything else came pretty much from local powers.

I suspect Selim becoming the first Ottoman Caliph contributed heavily to their later dissociation from openly claiming the title Roman Emperor for themselves.

Caliph in its purest form is a rather humble title meaning successor (of the Prophet). Ottoman Sultans like other Muslim rulers before them would style themselves "The Shadow of God on Earth" which is found originally in a hadith of the Prophet. Major scholars such as Al-Ghazali, As-Suyuti and Ibn Taymiyyah etc. had analysed and provided explanations of this narration. The hadith does not refer to rulers as shadows of God in the context of power but rather a place to which shade i.e. justice according to Islamic law could be sought. In the eyes of a Muslim ruler claiming such a role held heavy prestige.

The hadith was narrated by Ibn Umar the son of Caliph Umar

Ibn 'Umar reported the Prophet as saying, "The sultan is God's shade on the earth to which each one of His servants who is wronged repairs. When he is just he will have a reward, and it is the duty of the common people to be grateful; but when he acts tyrannically the burden rests on him, and it is the duty of the common people to show endurance."

This is getting very off topic, but the Roman Empire was as much of a state as anything pre ~1600. Perhaps more so. If you want to define "state" so narrowly that it can't be applied to any polity before then, you are of course free to do so; but that's not how most people use the term, especially in the given context.

Imperial Rome was certainly more of a state than, for example, Greek city-states or medieval feudal kingdoms. One way in which that's visible is that it had institutions that governed which existed beyond those that held sovereignty, ie, the Senate and the Imperial Bureaucracy were more than the citizen body or the Emperor. As for being decentralised, sure, the Roman empire was decentralised compared to modern states, but who said you had to be centralised to be a state? Besides, the Roman empire, especially after Diocletian, was vastly more centralised than anything comparable that came before (in the West at least). While the Imperial government gave provinces and cities some local autonomy, it was Rome's to give and take as it wished underlying just how centralised sovereignty and political legitimacy was, even if the day-to-day task of administration wasn't. And Rome kept a great deal: military matters, taxation, senior officials, grants for building projects, the (nominal) price of goods, etc... If you want to talk about abusing the term "state" then calling the cities under Roman control after Augustus "city-states" is a prime contender!
